original_master.name: 2006 Bootleg Recording (Live Audience Recording)
original_master.characteristics: Raw live recording, unprocessed, typical bootleg quality

reference_master.name: Matchering Remastered Version
reference_master.characteristics: Professionally remastered, enhanced frequency response and dynamics
reference_master.importance: CRITICAL - Shows automated mastering approach to live recording

loudness.note: Hot levels - peaks at ceiling already

dynamics.note: Moderate crest factor, high DR (characteristic of live recording)

frequency.note: VERY DARK - bootleg is extremely bass-heavy, missing treble

stereo.note: Narrow stereo - typical of bootleg recording (mono-ish)

dynamics.note: Expanded DR significantly (+23.5 dB) - major effect!

frequency.note: BRIGHTENED significantly - bootleg was too dark

loudness_changes.interpretation: Matchering made it louder while maintaining peak control

dynamics_changes.interpretation: MAJOR: DR expanded by 23.5 dB (bootleg very compressed)

frequency_changes.interpretation: Matchering BRIGHTENED the dark bootleg significantly

stereo_changes.interpretation: Stereo image expanded 122% - from narrow to wide

loudness.note: Very hot - peaks at ceiling, quieter RMS (more dynamic)

dynamics.note: Good crest factor (6.74), high DR - good dynamics

frequency.note: Dark bootleg (typical) - strong bass, missing treble

loudness.note: Much louder (+3.18 dB RMS), peaks optimized

dynamics.note: CF reduced but DR expanded 23.5 dB

frequency.note: Brightened but less dramatic than CD1T2

loudness_changes.interpretation: Significant loudness increase while preserving peaks

dynamics_changes.interpretation: Large CF reduction but consistent DR expansion

frequency_changes.interpretation: Less treble boost than CD1T2, but more bass reduction

bootleg_characteristics.dynamics: High DR but moderate CF (bootleg compression)
bootleg_characteristics.root_cause: Live concert recording artifact - bass-heavy, treble-lost, mono-ish

matchering_approach.assessment: Matchering corrected bootleg's darkness and mono-ness

key_findings: Bootleg is EXTREMELY dark (spectral centroid 374-571 Hz)
Matchering brightens by 439-599 Hz (HUGE shift to 973-1010 Hz)
Bootleg is VERY narrow stereo (0.17-0.23) - Matchering 100% wider (0.38-0.46)
Bass-to-mid ratio: Bootleg +13.6 to +16.8 dB → Matchering +10.4 to +12.3 dB
DR expansion is consistent +23.5 dB (likely different mastering approach)
Matchering adds 1-3 dB loudness while preserving peaks
Concert recording has very different baseline than studio recording

implications_for_auralis.important_note: Live concert recordings have VERY DIFFERENT characteristics than studio recordings
comparisons_made: Deep Purple Smoke On Water: Studio live recording
Porcupine Tree Rockpalast: Concert bootleg → Professional remaster

key_insights.discovery: Live bootlegs are extremely bass-heavy, treble-deficient
key_insights.implication: Need different EQ for live vs studio
key_insights.auralis_action: Concert audio needs MORE aggressive treble boost than studio

key_insights.discovery: Bootleg stereo is very narrow, Matchering expands 100%
key_insights.implication: Stereo expansion is valid mastering technique
key_insights.auralis_action: May benefit from stereo widening for live recordings

key_insights.discovery: Matchering increases DR despite increasing loudness
key_insights.auralis_action: Not just simple compression - intelligent processing

key_insights.discovery: Spectral centroid shift of 439-599 Hz is massive
key_insights.implication: Live recordings need fundamental tonal rebalancing
key_insights.auralis_action: Concert audio: reduce bass significantly, boost treble significantly
